abstract.text: In heavy-ion collisions at the LHC, the ALICE Collaboration is studying Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) matter at very high energy density where the formation of a Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP) is expected.
Quarkonium production is an important probe to characterize the QGP properties.

High precision data in pp collisions provide the baseline of Pb-Pb measurements and p-Pb collisions serve to quantify the amount of initial and/or final state effects, related to cold nuclear matter, that are largely unknown at the LHC energy.
Since 2010, the LHC provided Pb-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 2.76 TeV, pp collisions at various energies and in 2013 p-Pb collisions at √ s NN = 5.02 TeV.
In ALICE, quarkonia can be reconstructed at forward rapidity in the dimuon channel and at mid-rapidity in the dielectron channel, and, for both channels, down to zero transverse momentum.
New measurements on inclusive production of J/ψ, ψ(2S ) and Υ performed in p-Pb collisions and on the p T dependence of inclusive J/ψ in Pb-Pb collisions are presented.
The contribution of J/ψ from B hadrons to the inclusive production in Pb-Pb is also discussed.
Finally, an estimation of the cold nuclear matter effect in Pb-Pb, extrapolated from p-Pb measurements, is given.

The ALICE collaboration studies heavy-ion collisions at the LHC in order to investigate nuclear matter at very high energy density where the formation of a QGP is expected.

body_text.text: Experimental apparatus and data sample

The ALICE experiment [8] has in the central region (|η| < 0.9) detectors positioned in a large solenoidal magnet providing a uniform magnetic field of 0.5 T. The main tracking devices consist of the Inner Tracking System (ITS), made of six layers of silicon detectors that surround the beam pipe, and the Time Projection Chamber (TPC), a large cylindrical drift gas detector.

body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The ψ (2S ) was found to be more suppressed relatively to the J/ψ for both forward and backward rapidity and this behaviour is not explained by the models discussed in this paper [16,17,19,21].
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: For inclusive Υ (1S ), the measurements show a similar suppression than for the J/ψ , with, however, large uncertainties that do not allow to constrain the models.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In Pb-Pb collisions the p T dependence of the nuclear modification factor was measured at mid-rapidity and similar conclusion as for the published results at forward rapidity [4] were found: the J/ψ is less suppressed at low p T than at large p T and this behaviour is clearly different from low energy data.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In addition to the indication of a non-zero J/ψ elliptic flow in semi-central collisions [5], these results suggest a non-negligible contribution from J/ψ produced via combination of charm quarks in the QGP or at the phase boundary.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Finally, the contribution of CNM effects in Pb-Pb was extrapolated from the p-Pb measurement.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Under the assumptions described in this paper, R AA at low p T would be, once corrected for CNM effects, even higher than the measured one reinforcing the interpretation of a recombination mechanism.
